text:
Summarize (Orchestrating the Discussion)

Solutions and Strategies

Discuss the questions as a class. For the Initial Challenge ask the class how they found the difference between the teams’ scores. Have several pairs share their number sentences for the Initial Challenge. There are many ways each team could have arrived at their score. Take note of whether or not students offer different orders of scoring as different solutions. This may be a good opportunity to preview the Commutative Property, which will be discussed further in later questions and investigations.

Making the Mathematics Explicit

Suggested Questions:

  • What strategy did you use to determine each team’s new score after the sequence of points? (Answers will vary.)
  • How did you determine the difference in points for each pair of teams? (Answers will vary)
  • What would the number sentence be that reflects your reasoning? (Answers will vary)

In the Initial Challenge these are two explanations given by students on how they found the difference in points for a pair of teams:

Jonna: We added 500 and 150. The Know-It-Alls are 500 points below 0. It would take that many points just to get back up to 0. The Rocket Scientists are 150 points above 0, so it would take 650 points in all to get from the Know-It Alls’ score to the Rocket Scientists’ score.

Ty: The Super Brains are 300 points below zero, so they need 300 points to get to 0 and another 150 points to tie the Rocket Scientists. So, they are 450 points apart.

Using zero to describe the differences or changes in scores is an important idea for students at this stage of their understanding of integers and operations with integers. The teacher can illustrate these ideas on a number line as students describe them to help all students see the reasoning and how the number 0 is helpful.

For What If Situation A, ask students to explain how they found each team’s final score.

Here are some explanations students might give: (Problem Solving Environment)

Andre: We made a table to show what happened to the scores after each question.
The Super Brain's final score is equal to -150.
The Rocket Scientists final score is equal to -150.

Frida: We used a number line to keep track of the Rocket Scientists’ scores.

Rachael: The Super Brains had a score of -300. When they answered the 200-point question correctly, their score changed to -100. Then they missed a 150-point question, so their score went down to -250. Next, they got a 50-point question, so they went up to -200 points. Then they got another 50-point question, so their score went up again to -150. We wrote the number sentence: -300 + 200 - 150 + 50 + 50 = -150.

tiles.title: Number Line for Rocket Scientists' final score

text:
If the class does not provide these explanations, consider sharing them with your students to provide more strategy options.

  • Do these explanations make sense? Why? (Possible answer. Yes. Frida’s answer makes sense because she was able to use a number line to prove her ideas. Andre’s makes sense because he organized his work by using a table and working through the problem step-by-step. Rachael’s makes sense because she was able to use a number sentence to show how she found her answer.)
  • How do these explanations compare to your thinking? (Possible answer: I solved the problem like Rachael did, but I liked the way that André showed his work. He kept himself organized by using a table.)

This is a good opportunity to gather some formative assessment data on what the students understand about addition and subtraction relationships and about additive inverses.

  • For What If Situation B, who is correct? (They are both correct.) How can they both be correct? (Answers will vary. Students do not need to have a formal answer at this time. Having them express the idea of adding on points that they lost due to an incorrect answer and subtracting that number of points is a good foundation to build upon in the rest of the unit.)
  • For What If Situation C, which is correct? (both) How can they both be correct? (Answers will vary. You may want to use a number line to illustrate their conversations.)

For What If Situation D, ask students to share their strategies for finding the missing numbers in the number sentences. Focus particular attention on strategies for finding missing addends.

  • In Situation D, what do you notice about the missing values that you found? (Answers will vary.)
  • How did you determine the missing values? (Answers will vary. In Grade 6 students used fact families and guess and check to solve equations. These are strategies that students can use. Have students explain their use of these or other strategies. They will develop strategies using properties of equality in the Grade 7 unit, Moving Straight Ahead.)

Now What Do Students Know

Ask students to reflect on the discussion and answer the Now What Do You Know question.

Note: In Problem 1.1 it is an opportunity for students to informally work with addition and subtraction of integers. The

Reflecting on Student Learning  

Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.  

1. What evidence do I have that students understand the Now What Do You Know Question?

  • Where did my students get stuck?
  • What strategies did they use?
  • What breakthroughs did my students have today?

2. How will I use this to plan for tomorrow? For the next time I teach this lesson?

3. Where will I have the opportunity to reinforce these ideas as I continue through this Unit? The next Unit?
